awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Cross-Cultural Comparison of Conceptions of Property
awd_abstract_narration: This project will analyze popular understanding of intellectual property rights, test how intellectual property rights should work in various situations, investigate what people understand to be the purpose of intellectual property law, and study the role of culture in this understanding.  In doing so in cross-national comparative experiments, this project will move analysis of cultural understandings of law forward, for experiments have not yet been widely used to illuminate cultural understandings of law.  Furthermore, the broader impacts of the research are significant.  Intellectual property disputes are everywhere these days. Intellectual property law, including patent and copyright law, is built on the premise that offering people intellectual property rights will encourage potential inventors and authors to engage in more creative activity and innovation than they otherwise would. Intellectual property law can only work if potential inventors and authors know of the legal advantages in patents, if there are not side benefits to holding patents that can discourage innovation, and if intellectual property rights are generally self-enforcing. People cannot be incentivized to innovate if they are not aware of the incentives, and in many cases the law can only work for creators if there is widespread voluntary compliance.  These studies will provide insight into the ability of intellectual property law to function as intended, how people think about the ownership of intangible (versus tangible) property, and the ability of intellectual property law to affect human understanding and behavior. This new knowledge should shed light on how to modify the intellectual property system to better incentivize innovation and generate widespread user observance, as well as how to more effectively negotiate and implement intellectual property treaties with countries that have different intellectual property understandings.

por.por_cntn:
Though copying the work of others has occurred for hundreds or thousands of years, with the advent of the internet, it became increasingly easy to copy the creative works of others. Authorities struggle to reduce rates of downloading music and movies illegally and teachers and newspapers struggle to stop students and journalists from plagiarizing the work of others. With the funds from this grant, the research team was able to conduct many of the first studies about the psychology of intellectual property protection. Amongst the many discoveries was the existence of what we termed the Plagiarism Fallacy, or the idea that Americans mistakenly believe that intellectual property protections were created to stop plagiarism. In fact, the history of IP protections focuses more on incentivizing the creation of new creative works. The mistaken belief that IP protections are a guard against plagiarism likely underlies other mistaken beliefs we observed. Specifically, people believe it is more acceptable to copy someone’s work if you provide attribution to the source of that creative work. In fact, US IP law does not support this lay belief. We documented these findings in both a convenience and nationally-representative sample. Further, we observed that even American children share the intuition that attribution makes copying more acceptable. In addition to these specific findings, the funding from this grant supported training a graduate student, led to five professional presentations and four published papers on these topics, and resulted in large data sets that are all now publicly available for other researchers to analyze.
